questions.question: What is the definition of a 'Bus' in computer architecture?

options.text: A dedicated point-to-point circuit used exclusively between the CPU and RAM.
A shared communication link consisting of a group of electrical conductors transferring signals.
A software protocol that manages data flow within the operating system.
The physical plastic casing that holds the motherboard components together.

questions.explanation: A bus is a shared communication link, a group of electrical conductors that transfer signals between components, avoiding the need for separate circuits between every pair of devices.

questions.question: What constitutes a single 'Bus Line'?

options.text: A single conductor carrying a single electrical signal.
A bundle of 8 wires carrying a byte of data.
The connector slot used for the graphics card.
A software interrupt signal sent to the CPU.

questions.explanation: A bus line is defined as a single conductor (wire or PCB track) that is assigned a name and carries a single electrical signal.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the four main categories of bus lines?

options.text: Input, Output, Storage, and Processing lines.
Data, Address, Control, and Power lines.
USB, HDMI, Ethernet, and Audio lines.
Serial, Parallel, Simplex, and Duplex lines.

questions.explanation: The four main categories of bus lines are Data lines (carry data), Address lines (specify recipient), Control lines (synchronization), and Power lines (provide power).

questions.question: What is the primary function and characteristic of the Data Bus?

options.text: It carries control signals and is unidirectional.
It supplies power to the components and is non-directional.
It carries data between the CPU, memory, and I/O, and is bi-directional.
It carries memory addresses from the CPU and is unidirectional.

questions.explanation: The Data Bus carries data between the CPU and memory or I/O devices. It is bi-directional ('out of' CPU for write, 'into' CPU for read) .

questions.question: What is the specific role of the Address Bus?

options.text: It carries the data being processed and is bi-directional.
It carries the address from the CPU to memory or I/O and is unidirectional.
It carries synchronization signals like the system clock.
It provides the voltage required for the memory chips to operate.

questions.explanation: The Address Bus carries an address from the CPU to Memory or I/O devices. It is unidirectional because the address is always supplied by the CPU .

questions.question: Which specific signals are typically found in the Control Bus?

options.text: VCC, GND, +5V, +12V.
/RD (read), /WR (write), CLK (clock), /IRQ (interrupt).

questions.explanation: The Control Bus is a collection of signals for coordinating CPU activities, typically including /RD, /WR, CLK, and /IRQ .

questions.question: How do you calculate the total addressable memory if the address bus has 'k' bits and the data bus has 'n' bits?

options.text: Total Memory = 2^k * n bits.
Total Memory = 2^n * k bits.
Total Memory = k * n bits.
Total Memory = 2^(k+n) bits.

questions.explanation: With a k-bit address bus, there are 2^k addressable locations. If the word length (data bus) is n bits, the total memory is 2^k locations multiplied by n bits per location .

questions.question: Calculate the total memory size for a system with an 18-bit Address Bus and a 16-bit Data Bus.

options.text: 1 MB.
4 MB.

questions.explanation: 2^18 = 262,144 locations. Each location is 16 bits (2 bytes). Total = 262,144 * 2 bytes = 524,288 bytes = 512 KB.

questions.question: What are the two main types of Bus Topologies mentioned in the course?

options.text: Star and Mesh.
Ring and Bus.
Point-to-Point and Multipoint (Multidrop).
Serial and Parallel.

questions.explanation: The two main topologies are Point-to-Point (specific source to specific destination) and Multipoint/Multidrop (signals to several destinations) .

questions.question: What is the function of a Backplane or System Bus?

options.text: It connects the CPU with memory and I/O module cards in the same physical package.
It connects the computer to the internet via a modem.
It connects external peripherals like printers and scanners only.
It provides a dedicated link between the keyboard and the monitor.

questions.explanation: A Backplane or System Bus connects the CPU with memory and/or I/O module cards within the same physical package/chassis.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Bus Interface Unit or Bridge?

options.text: It provides a physical structure to hold the motherboard in the case.
It interfaces between different buses (e.g., varying bandwidths) to allow communication.
It generates the system clock signal for the CPU.
It acts as the main power supply regulator for the bus.

questions.explanation: Bridges or Bus Interface Units are interfaces between different buses that allow them to communicate, often connecting buses with different capacities .

questions.question: Which of the following is a list of common Backplane Buses mentioned?

options.text: USB, HDMI, and VGA.
Ethernet, Wi-Fi, and Bluetooth.
PCI, AGP, and ISA.
SATA, IDE, and SCSI.

questions.explanation: The course lists PCI (Peripheral Component Interconnect), AGP (Accelerated Graphics Port), and ISA (Industry Standard Architecture) as examples of backplane buses.

questions.question: What is a 'Bus Protocol'?

options.text: A hardware cable used to connect the bus.
The speed at which data travels on the bus.
A specification agreement defining the meaning of each bus line and signal.
The software driver installed for the chipset.

questions.explanation: A bus protocol is a specification that delineates the meaning of each bus line and signal, acting as an agreement between components on how to communicate.

questions.question: Which motherboard technology was developed by Intel in 1995 and became the standard for most desktop PCs?

options.text: AT (Advanced Technology).
Mini-ITX.
ATX (Advanced Technology Extended).
BTX (Balanced Technology eXtended).

questions.explanation: ATX was developed by Intel in 1995 and offers better power management and integrated I/O ports compared to the older AT standard.

questions.question: Which components are typically found connected directly to the motherboard?

options.text: Monitor screen and Keyboard keys.
CPU Socket, RAM Slots, and PCIe Slots.
Printer ink cartridges and Paper tray.
External Hard Drive USB cable.

questions.explanation: Common motherboard components include the CPU Socket, RAM Slots, PCIe Slots, Power Connectors, and Storage Connections .

questions.question: What defines a 'Multiprocessor System'?

options.text: A system with a single processor running multiple operating systems.
A system with two or more processors working together.
A system that uses multiple hard drives for storage.
A system connected to multiple monitors.

questions.explanation: A multiprocessor system is defined as a system with two or more processors working together to improve performance and scalability .

questions.question: What is a key characteristic of Symmetric Multiprocessing (SMP)?

options.text: Processors have a master-slave relationship.
Each processor has its own private memory and cannot access others.
Multiple processors share a single memory and I/O bus with equal access.
It is primarily used in low-power embedded systems.

questions.explanation: In SMP, multiple processors share a single memory and I/O bus, providing equal access to memory and balanced load distribution.

questions.question: What characterizes Asymmetric Multiprocessing (AMP)?

options.text: Processors are assigned specific tasks in a Master-Slave relationship.
All processors share the same workload equally.
It offers the highest possible scalability compared to SMP.
It requires all processors to be identical in speed and architecture.

questions.explanation: AMP involves processors assigned specific tasks with a master-slave relationship, where the master controls the system and slaves perform tasks.

questions.question: What are the two main types of Parallelism described?

options.text: Input Parallelism and Output Parallelism.
Memory Parallelism and Storage Parallelism.
Data Parallelism and Task Parallelism.
Hardware Parallelism and Software Parallelism.

questions.explanation: The course identifies Data Parallelism (processing data across multiple processors) and Task Parallelism (parallel execution of different tasks) .

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary challenge associated with Parallel Architectures?

options.text: Complexity in synchronization and data management.
Decreased throughput and performance.
Inability to use modern operating systems.
Limited availability of power supply units.

questions.explanation: While parallel architectures offer improved performance, a key challenge is the complexity involved in synchronization and data management.

questions.question: Which of the following are examples of modern multiprocessor systems mentioned?

options.text: Intel 8086 and Zilog Z80.
Intel Xeon and AMD Epyc.
Apple M1 and Snapdragon 888.
Arduino Uno and Raspberry Pi.

questions.explanation: The course lists Intel Xeon and AMD Epyc as examples of modern multiprocessor systems used in data centers and HPC.
